climbs.name: Serotonin
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, Whitney Leary, Jason Mons

content.description: Great, easy climb. Climb the east side of the prow, going up to climb a great arete. There is a slight overhang near the top, you can either climb over it, or go to the right and around it.
content.location: Far right (east) of the wall. Start just to the right of the prow.

content.description: Climb the large, easy pillar and clip the first bolt. The climb wanders left and right until you get to the top. Pretty sustained, great climb.
content.location: Left of Jack be Nimble. Look for the big pillar.

climbs.name: Old Glory
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, Mica Halling, Chace Merritt, Jason Mons,

content.description: One of the better 5.9s in the canyon. Climb just to the right of the big overhang. A few tricky moves to get on top of the overhang, but after that it's a breeze. There are many cool/different features on this climb. Make sure you are rappelling down the right side of the climb if you are using one rope.
content.location: Right side of the big overhang. There is a massive pile of bat guano to the left of the first bolt.

content.description: This route travels up a large, block-filled gully with superb views of Logan Canyon and the river far below. The book says it can be done in 1 or 2 pitches, but there was no obvious belay station, so I suggest cruising through in 1 pitch. The route has some loose, chossy holds and some loose pebble to cobble size rocks on it, so I advise both the climber and especially the belayer to wear helmets!  The climbing is easy and consistent at 5.5.  Protection is typical of Logan Canyon limestone: notoriously tricky to place solidly.  Luckily, spots for protection are numerous and hand holds abound.  Not a route to seek out in and of itself, but if you're up at Mullein land and have a trad rack with you, give it a shot.
content.protection: A standard rack up to a #3 camalot was used.  Be sure to bring several 24" runners to reduce rope drag (a killer on this route without them if you do it in one pitch). There are fixed chain anchors located just below the summit to the left.  We used a 70 m rope and rapped from the top using two ropes, just to be safe.  Old Glory's anchors are located below the top anchors, so I believe you could descend in two raps with a shorter rope.
content.location: This route is located in the gully directly to the right of Old Glory, before you walk around to the back side of Mullein Land.  Climb up this obvious gully using traditional pro.  At about 30 feet from the top, make sure you head left, as going right will make for an interesting exploration to find anchors/battle rope drag.

climbs.name: Mister Cruel
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, Jason Mons, Mica Halling, Chace Merrit,

content.description: This rout requires either a 70m rope or 2 60m ropes, unless you want to scramble up to the first bolt to belay. The crux is at the third bolt where there is a very cool lay back move. After the crux, the climb gets very chill. The chains are up on an awesome grassy ledge
content.location: Up a little gully a ways to the left (west) of the big overhang where Old Glory and Jack be Nimble are.

content.description:
Fun route.  The guidebook suggests two pitches, but it can easily be run together in one.  scramble or follow the crack to the left facing corner.  Enjoy nice hand jams or liebacking up to the large ledge.  Belay here if doing two pitches.  From here, there are two cracks taking you up to the next ledge.  Now follow the 'crack' looking thing in the center up to the top.  There are several cracks for building an anchor at the top.

Rap down from the 'Mister Cruel' anchors with a single 70 m.
content.location: This climb starts in the large corner to the right of Bellingham and Mister Cruel.

climbs.name: Labor and Delivery
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, John Louviere, Becca Louviere

content.description: This is an awesome little crack climb on the very far left wall of Mullein Lands. It might be a little difficult to spot, but if you just look for a little tree on the rocks, you can spot the chains right next to them.
content.protection: Crack sizes vary from finger to fist, rack accordingly
content.location: Far left of all the bolted routs. The crack lies on a little arete. The chains are located next to a little tree hanging out on the wall.

climbs.name: Jack Be Nimble
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, B. Frankel, Isaac Halling

content.description: Climb the left face of the big overhang. Crux is from the start to the first ledge, where it get a little balancy. Once you are on the ledge, climb up the crack to the right. Great Climb!
content.location: Located to the left of the giant overhang.

climbs.name: I'm blue, I'm a dog, I'm a dog.

content.description:
Start from the ground for a harder boulder problem or skip the awkward start and traverse in from the right from on top of the boulders.  Go straight up two bolts.  Trend right 3 bolts afterwards.  Leftward is 'Blackstreak Boys'.

Surprisingly pumpy route or I was tired from drilling on lead.  Some sort of 5.11 with the boulder problem and a .10 without.  Get out and climb it!  Lots of a little pebbles hanging on to this one, so be aware of that.
content.location: Left of the small boulders between Final Hurrah and Jack be nimble.

content.description:
Face climb to a roof followed by a side-pull crack to the chains. The first 2 bolts have good holds and the movement can be a little extended for short people. The roof is a crimp with a sharp under-cling to move to the nose.

This route is dedicated to Justin Graham, one of the best climbers Logan has ever known. He lived fearlessly and loved climbing in the realm of the overhang.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchors. Bring 7 draws and you're good.
content.location: The most prominent roof of the crag.  Starts immediately right of Jack be Nimble. first bolt is 2 feet up and right.

content.description: Hard moves off the ground, then easier above the small overhang.
content.location: Left of Blackstreak boys/I'm Blue in the steepest part of the main wall of Mullein Land. First bolt best clipped with a stick clip.

climbs.name: Bowling for Cars
climbs.fa: potential 1st assent Brian Hess and Michael Ward

content.description: This fun route can be climbed in 1 or 2 pitches, I think it climbs better as a single pitch.  The route climbs double cracks up an arete to a big ledge.  From the ledge climb the obvious splitter up the face on/left of arete.  FYI cracks on this climb are surprisingly clean of dirt, grass and bushes.
content.protection: Nuts, single rack of cams up to 2 BD.
content.location: This route is located on the next cliff east of serotonin.  The descent is a walk off down the gully just west/down canyon from the route.

content.description:
Climb the first two bolts of "I'm Blue"  Head left from the second bolt to the black streak.  Climb the black streak to the anchors.

Crux comes between the second and third bolt, and may feel a bit exposed.

Great route and position.  Somewhere in the 11+/12- range.

climbs.name: Bellingham Blues
climbs.fa: Eric Newell, Jason Mons, Mica Halling, Chace Merrit,

content.description: Climb the arete to the left of Mister Cruel. Stay left of the prow for 5.8 climbing or you can go to the right of the prow for 5.10 climbing.
content.location: Climb the Arete just to the left of Mister Cruel

content.description: Very fun, easy climb. There are a couple of slick parts between the 1st and 2nd bolts, but it isn't too bad.
content.protection: 7 Bolts, chain anchors. Possible to place some smaller gear.
content.location: This is the first climb you will come to. It is just off the trail, before you get to the main crag of Mullein Lands.
